multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a skin eruption that has been around for 2 weeks, joint pain, and my gums have been bleeding.
Have you noticed any recent changes in your medications or started new drugs prior to these symptoms appearing?
No, I haven't started any new medications or drugs recently.
Do you have any previous history of similar symptoms or any other chronic illnesses?
I have a history of anorexia nervosa and alcoholism, but no history of similar skin symptoms or other chronic illnesses.
Have any other members of your family experienced similar symptoms, or do they have a history of autoimmune or connective tissue diseases?
No, there is no family history of similar symptoms or autoimmune or connective tissue diseases.
What is the appearance of the skin eruption? Can you describe the size, color, and whether it's itchy or painful?
The skin eruption consists of purplish spots and raised bumps that look like they involve hair follicles. There are also some areas with bruises. The eruptions are not itchy or painful.

Considering the skin eruptions, joint pain, and bleeding gums alongside a history of anorexia and alcoholism, can you tell me if you have noticed any other symptoms like fatigue, headache, or changes in vision?
No, I haven't experienced fatigue, headaches, or changes in vision.
Final Diagnosis: Scurvy.
